concern:
TW: self harm 

I am a 5th year in college who is non-traditional student aged. I was previously academically dismissed and worked so hard to get back into my college and I did! The community college classes I took in the time between was so easy and I didn’t really learn to cultivate better habits as I was able to quickly do work and still get As, which felt good, but not the same at a 4 year college. I have been diagnosed with ADHD/ anxiety/ depression since the 5th grade and didn’t start utilizing accommodations until high school. Used them and did great. College is another story as I started to having to advocate for myself and thought all of my negative symptoms were how everyone felt and who I was. I never saw those things as barriers, but as I have gotten older, the dots have started clicking. I have been embarrassed to use my accommodations until this year because past friends made comments that it’s unfair and I took those to heart. The academic resource center purged my files upon my dismissal so it’s been a mess trying to get the correct documentation and my doctor only sent in the documentation last week even though I was asking for months. I am very frustrated as I’ve been falling behind due to my mental health rapidly declining this semester upon starting a new medication that made everything worse: insomnia, more anxiety, not taking care of myself, thoughts of unaliving myself, and started c*tting myself for a few weeks. I started to make the connection that it was my new med I started and then cut it cold Turkey and have felt better, but I’m still in a disassociative state making functioning hard. I am scared to disclose all of this as I can’t afford to medically withdraw and am supposed to graduate in the spring. I would appreciate any advice for how to handle this

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here. Please feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. I'm just really overwhelmed with school and my mental health right now, and I feel like I'm kind of stuck in a loop.
It sounds tough feeling overwhelmed and stuck. Could you share more about what's been weighing on you with school and your mental health?

client: Yeah, it's just been a lot to juggle between trying to keep up with classes and dealing with my mental health getting worse. I thought I was managing okay, but it kind of spiraled recently, and I'm struggling to keep up.
It seems like you're feeling a lot of pressure trying to balance everything, and it's become overwhelming. What do you think led to things spiraling recently?
client: I think it started when I switched medications. I thought it would help, but it made everything worse, and now I'm just trying to pick up the pieces and catch up with everything.
Switching medications and feeling worse sounds really challenging. How do you envision things changing if you could find a better balance with school and your mental health?
I just want to feel in control again and not be constantly worried about falling behind. It'd be nice to handle my schoolwork without it feeling like it's this massive weight on me all the time.
That desire to regain control and lighten the weight sounds really important to you. What small steps do you think could help you start moving toward that sense of control?

Maybe I can start by setting up a more structured daily routine to help me stay on track and using my accommodations more effectively. Also, I think reaching out to professors to explain my situation might help ease some of the academic pressure.
It sounds like you're identifying some practical steps. How do you feel about reaching out to your professors and setting up that routine?

I feel a bit anxious about reaching out to them because I worry about being judged or seen as making excuses. As for the routine, I think it could help, but I’m worried about sticking to it, especially on rough days.
Your concerns about judgment and sticking to a routine seem really valid. How might taking these steps align with your broader goals of feeling more in control?

I guess taking these steps could help me feel a bit more organized and less overwhelmed, which would be a step toward feeling more in control. If I can manage to communicate my needs and have a routine, maybe I'd start to feel like I'm not just constantly scrambling to keep up.

It sounds like having a structured routine and communicating with your professors could be key steps towards your goal of feeling more in control. Would it be helpful to discuss how you might approach these actions and any specific strategies to ease those feelings of anxiety and ensure you can maintain the routine, even on tough days?

Yeah, I think having some strategies in mind would be really helpful. It would be great to have a plan for communicating with my professors and keeping up the routine, especially when things get tough.

Based on what you said, possible options could include setting small, manageable goals for communication, like drafting emails or setting specific times to reach out, and creating a flexible routine that allows for adjustments on tougher days. How does that sound to you?
That sounds like a really good starting point. Having smaller goals feels less overwhelming and a flexible routine could definitely help on days when things aren't going as planned.
Would you like to identify a specific goal for your communication or routine to start with, and think about what steps you might take to put these plans into action?
Yeah, that sounds like a smart move. Maybe starting with drafting an email to one of my professors could be a good first goal, and we could figure out what steps to include in that.
That sounds like a great first step. Perhaps we could outline the key points you want to include in the email and decide when you’d like to send it. How does that sound?
Yeah, outlining the key points would be really helpful. I think having a rough draft of what to say would make it feel less daunting.

You've made a solid plan today by deciding to draft an email to your professor, which is a great first step towards managing your workload and reducing stress. Remember, you've got a flexible routine now to adjust on challenging days, which should help keep things balanced. Be proud of yourself for recognizing what you need and taking action. When you're ready, go ahead with the email draft; that will be a significant move forward. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need more guidance or support. You've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement. I'll definitely work on that draft and try to keep things balanced.

You're doing great by taking these proactive steps. Drafting that email and establishing a flexible routine are significant strides in managing your stress and workload. Remember, progress is a journey, and you're on the right path. Keep nurturing your well-being, and reach out if you need any support along the way. You've got a solid plan, and I'm here to help you keep moving forward. You've got this!
Thanks, I'll keep that in mind. I just hope I can keep up with everything.
